1.title: A System of Integrated Tools
1.content: Developed over many years to solve real-world problems, MrWatson‚Äôs tools have come to cover a wide range of tasks and problems that I and many other FileMaker developers encounter regularly during their daily routine. The tools can solve problems . | during setup of a FileMaker workplace computer | throughout all aspects of the development process | when analysing and debugging databases | during deployment and patching | with integrating documentation | . To help you understand where the tools fit into the FileMaker development ecosystem, and how they work together, here is a schematic overview: .

8.title: Another Variable Typo!?
8.content: Don‚Äôt say I didn‚Äôt tell you! ü§¨ . You use variables, right? . We all use variables! . They‚Äôre fantastic! . Yes! . Except, of course, when they are not! üôÅ . The Problem . ‚Ä¶is, of course, when you have a typo in a variable name - or have forgotten to define a variable. And that is sadly far too easy to do! . FileMaker offers no help here at all. For example, you might have a script that looks like this: . Set Variable [ $AttachementNumber ; 1 ] Set Variable [ $AttachementCount ; Count( Email.Attachments::pk ) ] Loop Exit Loop If [ $AttachementNumber > $AttachementCount ] # Process attachment Set Variable [ $Filename ; GetNthRecord( Email.Attachments::Filename ; $AttachmentNumber) ] # : Set Variable [ $AttatchmentNumber ; $AttatchmentNumber + 1 ] End Loop . Can you spot the mistake(s)? . üßê Doh! ü§Ø . | but don‚Äôt worry, you have good friends at hand to help! | . MrWatson‚Äôs Solution 1: Copy + Paste . My first solution was to simply always copy and paste variable names. It‚Äôs not a bad solution - and I still use it today - just watch out for accidentally doubled up $$ characters when selecting and replacing variable names! . MBS Plugin Solution: Variable Checking . Then Christian Schmitz started a wonder solution with the MBS Plugin ‚Ä¶ variable checking! . FIXME IMAGE . MBS clearly flags up undefined variables, so long as you play by . The Rules of the Game . | Turn on MBS Plugin‚Äôs VariableChecking Option . | Watch out for - and catch - all your undefined variables (& typos!) | . | Always define your variables . | Don‚Äôt use Let to define your variables, use Set Variable. | If you‚Äôve never done this before it might seem like an enormous drag and waste of time but, believe me, it is worth it! | . | Don‚Äôt use spaces in your variable names | If you have long scripts you‚Äôll need to increase the number of script lines MBS scans | . Best Practice Tips . | Use variables to make your code more self descriptive & readable. | Define your variables at the start of the script . | Don‚Äôt use Let to define your variables | Don‚Äôt use a custom function to define your variables automatically | . | Use a # @var $variableName comment to declare variables where MBS can‚Äôt recognise the definition . | For example: before an Insert Calculated Result script step | . | Avoid using $$ variables throughout scripts . | Instead read the value into a normal $variable, and output the $$variable again at the end. | . | Avoid re-using variable names for different things in different parts of the script | Be aware, that in long steps and calculations the step text is truncated, so the MBS Plugin may may miss ome variable references. | . MrWatson‚Äôs Solution 2: fmSyntaxColorizer . | fmSyntaxColorizer | and a useful code transformation to change all variable names in a script to be MBS-friendly | .

11.content: Introduction . | Need to transfer some FileMaker code from here to there across the internet quick? | Wanna copy and paste your FileMaker code between two FileMaker solutions - and it just doesn‚Äôt work? | . The Problem . | Copy and paste doesn‚Äôt work for FileMaker code. (at least not from a Mac.) | However, copy and paste does work for text. (most of the time) | . 16.doc: Backporting an e-Invoice Solution for GBS GmbH
16.title: The Setting
16.content: The technical specification EN16931 has long prepared the path for electonic invoicing in the EU.At first there was a slow uptake from the commercial sector, but towards the end of 2024 in Germany at last the penny dropped‚Ä¶ . electronic invoicing is really coming to Germany . ‚Ä¶and quite imminently! . Moreover, the task ahead had just exploded, morphing . | from the (relatively) simple task of receiving an electonic invoice | to the much more complicated task of generating and sending a valid electonic invoice. | .

17.doc: Backporting an e-Invoice Solution for GBS GmbH
17.title: An e-Invoicing Solution
17.content: At G√ºnther Business Solutions GmbH we scrambled to master the situation - and managed to create a great solution in a couple of very intensive months‚Äô consultation and programming. The solution we developed for the advanter ERP system was a two file module: one file for the code and one for the customer‚Äôs data.

18.doc: Backporting an e-Invoice Solution for GBS GmbH
18.title: The Problem
18.content: Whilst our prefered delivery method would have been to update all our customers to this new version of the software, there was a problem: . A handful of customers - about 15 - were stranded in old legacy versions of the software, requiring GBS to backport this new functionality into their old systems. üòï .

19.doc: Backporting an e-Invoice Solution for GBS GmbH
19.title: The Headaches of Backporting Code
19.content: As you may know, backporting code into old databases is always a real headache. Databases evolve over time, and it is only natural that things get improved, renamed, extended, restructured. Importing or copy-pasting code between different versions of a database always leads to broken code, and we needed to minimise / eradicate this risk. Whilst the files were designed to be modular, there was a still a rather large overhead of programming that was needed in the legacy systems to integrate these modules into the legacy framework. The to do list included, amongst many other things . | ensuring a clean programming environment | deploying the two new files to the customers server | integrating the two new files into advanter‚Äôs standard processes, inc. | file authorisation, account & window management, solution startup & shutdown, etc. | . | adding or updating code to support the new e-Invoice process: . | custom functions, fields, value lists, layouts, scripts, ‚Ä¶ | settings fields for the e-Invoice process | new, normalised line item table to pre-process the data | modifying the invoice print script to construct the electronic invoice data as json and interact with the new e-Invoice module | . | . In other words, . | a lot of manual changes | in a lot of different systems | . We needed to get efficient! .

20.doc: Backporting an e-Invoice Solution for GBS GmbH
20.title: MrWatson‚Äôs Tools to the rescue!
20.content: MrWatson‚Äôs tools proved to be most useful in many aspects of this process! . Here is a list of the tools we used, and how they helped. | MrWatson‚Äôs fmWorkMate toolbox, with all its magic‚Ä¶ | fmLaunchPad . | to speed up te database launch process | and to make it easier for fmWorkMate to run in a separate FileMaker instance | . | Setup tools . | fmSetupAssistant . | to make sure that the FileMaker programming environment on the customers computer was setup correctly | . | fmKillDefaultFields . | to make sure that the customer‚Äôs database was clean of default fields | . | fmSyntaxColorizer . | to make sure that errors in scripts were immediately visible | . | . | fmCheckmate . | to transfer code from our master database to the customer‚Äôs deployment | . | fmAutoMate . | to transfer code even quicker using Xopy ‚Äòn‚Äô PaXte | . | fmLogAnalyzer and the BugOff! Alarm . | to catch pasting errors as we made them | and to turn the errors in a still-to-do list | . | fmCheckMate-XSLT library . | primarily for layout analysis to check no pasting errors crept into customers‚Äô layouts. | . | fmDBAnalyzer . | for the specific task of checking the new TOs in the relationship graph. | . | fmTextDiff . | to check how the customer‚Äôs code and our code differed | . | . The tool, however, which really shone in this process wasfmIDE .

21.title: A To-Do List Solution: Slack Canvas
21.content: For the ToDo list we had chosen to use the Slack Canvas functionality just released in our team software of choice, Slack. Thanks to the brand spanking new Slack Canvas functionality in our team software of choice, Slack, it was relatively easy to build a comprehensive - but collapsible - to do list, that worked for everyone. | Slack Canvas to build a comprehensive & collapsible to do list | .

25.content: Just Open that Script! . FileMaker got a great new feature quite a few versions back, where you can ‚åòClick on a Perform Script script step and it opens the script for you. This is a great feature to help you to follow the script-flow but‚Ä¶ .

26.content: ‚Ä¶it only works within one file. If you have a multifile solution, where scripts jump between files, I‚Äôm afraid you are out of luck! .

27.title: MrWatson‚Äôs Solution
27.content: Just add a little of MrWatson‚Äôs tonic, wave your magic wand - ‚åÉ‚åòO - and Open Sesame! the script will magically open for you. The tonic you need is . | fmAutoMate | fmIDE! | and, of course, the MBS Plugin | . fmAutoMate extends the FileMaker development environment to provide extra menu items and keyboard shortcuts to make your life easier. fmIDE (a FileMaker Integrated Devlopment Environment) is a script/script module that you can add to your solution to provide unbelievable power to your development environment.

33.doc: Create Multiple FileMaker Apps on Mac OS
33.title: Create Multiple FileMaker Apps on Mac OS
33.content: Ooooooh nice! . This page is under contruction! . Did you know that on Mac OS you can not only have multiple versions of FileMaker installed on your computer, but also multiple instances of the same version? . Just duplicate, rename and re-iconise the FileMaker app, and you can have multiple beautiful FileMaker based apps in your dock: . How to Create a FileMaker App on Mac OS . Here is how to create a FileMaker App, using the MrWatson in the Table of Doom App as an example . 1. Duplicate the FileMaker App . | Select your standard FileMaker app in the Finder | Duplicate it ‚åòD | . 2. Rename the App . | Press ‚èé and give it a new, unique, zingy, iconic name | and, if you need to group it with some app FileMaker files, put it in a new folder of the same name and throw in the app‚Äôs FileMaker files | . 3. Re-iconise the App . | Create a new icon for your FileMaker app | Select the FileMaker app | Show the Information window ‚åòI or right click and select ‚ÄòGet Info‚Äô | Drag your new icon to the file icon at the top left of the Get Info window | . 4. Setup fmLaunchPad to handle your app . | Open fmLaunchPad | Change to List view | Add a new module . | easiest by duplicating and editing an existing module | . | Edit the trigger condition to recognise your app . | For example: "MrWatson in the Table of Doom" = fmAppName . | Note: I tend to put the name before the = sign, since this acts better as a title for the section | . | There are a few Custom Functions you can use to make it easier‚Ä¶ . | fmAppName, fmAppFolder | See the (?) button in fmLaunchPad for more information | . | . | Change the type of the module to Launch App File . | This will open a file relative to the location of the app file | . | Type the name of the file to start . | no .fmp12 extension needed | if the file is in a subfolder then use ¬´foldername¬ª/¬´filename¬ª | . | Change the name of the module displayed on the module wall . | The field accepts two lines | the first line is the name for the left wall | the second line is the name for the right wall | . | In the Settings popup you can choose [X] Capsule Mission | . Voil√°! Your new FileMaker app is ready to go! .

37.title: Did That Just Break?
37.content: When something breaks in a forest, does it make a noise? . Introduction . And when something breaks in a FileMaker database, does it log an error? . When moving code around, patching files, or generally copy + pasting stuff from A to B, it‚Äôs quite easy to break things. FileMaker tries to help in the form of the import.log which gets written to every time you paste something in, but‚Ä¶ . The Problems . | The import.log is hard to read | Some problems are not logged as errors | Errors from cancelled imports are hard to recognise | Finding the error in the log is one thing, finding the original error is another | Custom functions errors are not logged | In Layout Mode there is no logging at all | . MrWatson‚Äôs Solutions . MrWatson has a solution for everything . For Mastering the import.log . First and foremost you need fmLogAnalyser to help you read the import.log, and the BugOff! Alarm to tell you when you‚Äôve broken something. This solves problems 1-3. Errors and warnings (e.g. thing ‚Äòx‚Äô imported as thing ‚Äòx 2‚Äô) are highlighted and a big green OK button tells you your import was successful. For problem 4, you need to add fmIDE to your solution. Then it needs approximately a single click to get to the error in your solution The tonic you need is . Problem 5 and 6, errors in Custom Functions and Layouts, have to be solved differently, since they are not logged. For this you need . | fmCheckMate (part of fmWorkMate) | fmCheckMate XSLT-Library! | and, of course, the MBS Plugin | . For Custom Functions . ‚Ä¶after you paste them in, but before you close the Custom Functions dialog,‚Ä¶ . | Copy the Custom Functions back to the clipboard | With fmCheckMate convert them to XML | Click [T] (or press‚åòT) to choose an XSLT transformation | Select the analysis function ‚ÄúList functions that seem to be commented out‚Äù | You get a list of suspect CFs | . If the list is empty, you can go back and save the custom functions, and if not you can break off, fix the problems and repeat. For Layouts . | Copy the layout objects back to the clipboard | With fmCheckMate convert them to XML | Click [T] (or press‚åòT) to choose an XSLT transformation | Select the analysis function ‚ÄúLayout Analysis‚Äù | You get a neat list of all the errors and warnings in the layout | .

39.doc: Dock Script Window to Script Workspace
39.title: Dock Script Window to Script Workspace
39.content: You don‚Äôt need to get stuck in a GUI dead-end! . Introduction . FileMaker has a pretty neat debugger, with a very useful button for editing the current script, which allows you to open the script and break off the debugging. It‚Äôs a quick way to get to a script directly from a button or process,‚Ä¶ however‚Ä¶ . The Problem . when you edit the currently running script, you get a standalone editing window for editing the steps of the script, which lacks many of the niceties of being in the script workspace. For example, you are not able to see where the script is in the script tree, or to duplicate the script. Morevover, there is no way to easily get back to editing this script in the Script Workspace, other than closing the window, opening the Script workspace and going to find the same script (and good luck with that!) . You get stuck in a bit of a GUI dead-end, which doesn‚Äôt feel nice - even the 100th time you find yourself there . MrWatson‚Äôs Solution . Two of MrWatson‚Äôs integration tools to the rescue! . | fmAutoMate | fmIDE | . Having installed fmAutoMate in the current FileMaker and having built fmIDE into your solution files, you simply right click in the script editing window to show the fmAutoMate menu and select fmIDE > Dock Window to Script Workspace, and the script window will be docked to the script workspace.

81.title: fmGraphIt
81.content: Connect the dots . fmGraphIt helps you visualize the field dependencies of your FileMaker database tables. Fed up of trawling though field definitions to understand how fields hang together? . ‚û° A picture is worth a thousand words! . Just copy the fields and get the big picture with fmGraphIt in a few clicks! . Iif you have a FileMaker Database with a table (or two) of unknown, confusing, or down right mysterious fields‚Ä¶ . ‚Ä¶you need fmGraphIt! .

82.title: Installing fmGraphIt
82.content: fmGraphIt is a process, not a tool. 1 fmGraphIt is, indeed, not a seperate tool of it‚Äôs own üò≥, rather it is a process using some of the tools in MrWatson‚Äôs toolkit.

83.title: What do you need?
83.content: To generate a field dependency graph from the field definitions of one table you will need . | MrWatson‚Äôs fmWorkMate toolbox (which includes the fmCheckMate tool) | . | Download the latest release of fmWorkMate from GitHub | . | MrWatson‚Äôs fmCheckMate-XSLT Library (which includes the graph creation function) | . | Download the latest release of fmCheckMate-XSLT from GitHub | . | To visualise this field dependency graph you will need a graph visualisation tool. | . | The free yEd software from yWorks . | Download the latesyt version of yEd from yWorks | . | . | some yEd configuration files for formatting the graph (which are to be found in the xml/yEd folder of The fmCheckMate-XSLT Library) . | Finally, you need . | . | A step-by-step guide to installing fmGraphIt ( fmWorkMate, the fmCheckMate-XSLT Library, and yEd) | A tutorial on creating your first Field Dependency Graph | A Field Dependency Graph Legend | An introduction to yEd | .

84.title: Installing fmGraphIt - Step by Step
84.content: You need to download, install ans setup the following components: . | Download & Install fmWorkMate | Download & Install fmCheckMate-XSLT Library | Setup fmWorkMate & fmCheckMate | Download & Install yEd | Setup yEd | . 1. Download & Install fmWorkMate . Download fmWorkMate from the [fmWorkMate Repo] and follow the installation instructions in the Readme file. 2. Download & Install fmCheckMate-XSLT library . Download the ** fmCheckMate-XSLT Library** from the [fmCheckMate-XSLT Library Repo] and follow the installation instructions in the Readme file. 3. Setup fmWorkMate & fmCheckMate . You need to . | Follow the instructions in the fmWorkMate Readme to setup the MBS and Base Elements plugins in the fmWorkMate Settings page (i) | In fmCheckMate load the XSLT | . 4. Download & Install yEd . | Download and install the free yEd editor from the [yWorks yEd Editor download page] | Move the app file to your applications folder | . 5. Setup yEd . The Properties mapper needs to be configured . | From the menus select Edit > Properties Mapper... | Press the green down arrow button to import additional configurations. | Navigate to the ~Documents/fmCheckMate/xml/yEd/fmFieldDependencyGraph Folder | Load the latest FDG_yEdPropertyMap*.cnfx file. | Press [Ok] to exit | . üÜó . üëå OK, we are finally ready to go! .

85.title: Disclaimer
85.content: Before you jump into fmGraphIt you should understand its limits: . fmGraphIt‚Äôs Field dependency graphs are not rocket science - it‚Äôs not even always right - but it is just about as quick an overview of field structure as you can get in a few clicks without having to create a DDR! . The problem is that since the FileMaker clipboard only contains field calculations as a string, the calculation must be parsed. Since I am no rocket scientist, that means fmGraphIt builds its list of field dependencies by just looking (relatively unintelligently) for occurrences of the field names in the calculations. Sometimes fmGraphIt gets it wrong, for example fmGraphIt ignores relationships, so if a referenced field in a related table has the same name as a field in the current table, fmGraphIt will incorrectly consider this as a reference to a field in the current table. See ‚ÄòHow fmGraphIt works‚Äô to get a better understanding of its limits.

98.title: fmKillDefaultFields
98.content: Kill First, Ask Qs Later . When Claris introduced default fields they were both a blessing and a curse. A blessing for those who need them, a curse for those who don‚Äôt. For those of us who don‚Äôt need them, this utility gives you a one button solution to remove your default fields, no questions asked.

104.title: fmLaunchPad
104.content: 3 ‚Ä¢ 2 ‚Ä¢ 1 ‚Ä¢ FileMaker is GO ! . This page is under contruction! . fmLaunchpad is a solution to the conceptionally flawed ‚Äòopen file on start‚Äô functionality in FileMaker. The Problems of ‚Äòopen file on start‚Äô . Whilst the idea to open a file automatically on start is a great one, the implementation that Claris gave us is sadly far less than ideal for the majority of FileMaker users/developers, because it is incompatible with double-clicking a file to open it. In other words: . With ‚Äòopen file on start‚Äô FileMaker ignores the user‚Äôs request to open a different file. A second problem of the ‚Äòopen file on start‚Äô functionality is that . only one setting applies to all versions and instances of the FileMaker App on the computer. This is a shame, because so much more could be possible. Multiple FileMaker Apps (need multiple start files) . Did you know that on Mac OS you can not only have multiple versions of FileMaker installed on your computer, but also multiple instances of the same version? . Just duplicate, rename and re-iconise the FileMaker app, and you can have multiple beautiful FileMaker based apps in your dock: . But, of course, each of these apps needs a different start file, and that‚Äôs where the ‚Äòopen file on start‚Äô functionality falls down. The Solution . or, indeed, with fmLaunchPad is possible! .

130.content: There‚Äôs no better substitute . fmCheckMate is great for doing a single search and replace, or maybe a few, but it becomes hard work when you have a whole list of changes that you need to make. That‚Äôs where fmTextConverter comes in. fmTextConverter is basically a wrapper for the FileMaker Substitute function, and lets you specify a list of search and replace pairs, and then apply them all in one go. Killer Keyboard Mode . 132.title: fmTextDiff
132.content: Makes all the difference. One of my favourite tools, fmTextDiff is a simple but powerful tool that ‚Äòmakes all the difference‚Äô when you need to compare two files, texts or even FileMaker code straight up! . The Problem . Very often we need to know what the differences are between two versions of a database, in order to know what has changed. When faced with a whole bunch of scripts, pages and pages of script steps, or a long list of fields, the job of finding all the differences can lie somewhere on the scale from daunting to impossible. Yes, there are analysis tools that can help, but they often only work on the entire-database level and require hours to run. The Solution . fmTextDiff works like you work, allowing you to concentrate on one bit at a time. If you can copy it from FileMaker, you can diff it with fmTextDiff! . Just . | copy the thing you want to compare out of the old FileMaker version, . | when copying locally use ‚åòC with fmAutoMate from a remote Mac use ‚åÉ‚åòC to Xopy the code as XML to the local clipboard, from remote mac use ‚åòC + fmCheckMate to transfer code between computers from remote windows use ‚åÉC + old fmWorkMate runtime > fmCheckMate | . | paste it into fmTextDiff . | open fmTextDiff from fmWorkMate with ‚åò7, | in fmTextDiff press ‚åò7 to paste the code into the next free (left) slot, | . | copy the equivalent thing out of the new FileMaker version | press ‚åò7 in fmTextDiff again to paste the code into the next free (right) slot . | fmTextDiff automatically starts diffing the two pieces of code. | . | . Note that as you insert the code, fmTextDiff asks fmCheckMate to convert the code to the best text format for diffing: . Scripts & Steps a one-line-per-step representation of the script. Tables and Fields a one-line-per-field representation of the field and calculation. Custom Functions a one-line-per-function representation of the function. How to . | To compare files, | To compare texts | To compare code on the clipboard | .

134.title: fmTextMultiplier‚Äôs Open Top Sandwich Function
134.content: Multiplies your ButtonBar, Slider and TabControl contents . The new sandwich function in fmTextMultiplier is a game changer. It allows you to multiply the contents of your ButtonBars, Sliders and TabControls. When you insert one of these layout object types, the sandwich icon appears, something like this: . Press it to ‚Äòopen up the sandwich‚Äô and remove the outer layer of the object. This will reveal the contents of the object allowing you to multiply up the contents. Once you have multiplied the contents, you can ‚Äòclose the sandwich‚Äô by pressing the ultimate-sandwich icon at the bottom right corner of the page. You can see the sandwich pieces on the sandwich popover: . On the popover‚Ä¶ . | [Close Sandwich] puts the bread around the contents again (without multiplying the innards), | [Clear Sandwich] ‚Äòthrows away the bread‚Äô | or you can manually edit the xml if needed | .

187.title: How does this table work?
187.content: Getting the big picture is not easy . Understanding how a table works or how the fields of a table hang together can sometimes be a daunting task, and a real grind, particularly if . | the table is complex / there are many or deeply nested field calculations | you are new to the table or returning to a table after a long time | the purpose of a table is unclear | the field naming conventions are different to your daily style | there is no documentation (which, of course, I am assuming is the case) | .

188.title: The Problem
188.content: . Clicking through a table‚Äôs field definitions in FileMaker is not a particularly efficient way to get an overview of how a table works. Calculations can be complex, long, or deep, and you may have to open and close many field calculation definitions and take notes to piece together how the fields hang together to make the table work. Moreover, when Auto Enter calculations are used, it makes it even harder: . | you have to make double the amount of clicks, | they obscure which fields are input fields and which are output fields! | . All in all It‚Äôs hard to get the big picture, and it can take a lot of time to get a good overview of how a table works! . Fed up of trawling though field definitions to understand how fields hang together? .

189.title: MrWatson‚Äôs Solution
189.content: With fmGraphIt you can just copy the fields and with a few clicks get the big picture! . | A picture is worth a thousand words! | A detailed network with tooltip calculations is worth far more than a thousand words! | .

193.title: Import a Table Perfectly
193.content: The devil is in the detail . Introduction . So‚Ä¶ . | you‚Äôve built your table into the wrong file? | or you‚Äôre refactoring your database and a table has to move to a new home? | or maybe you‚Äôre building some new functionality into a customer‚Äôs old version of your database? | . No problem! FileMaker has an import table function! All I have to do is‚Ä¶ . | Import the table from the source file | Redirect existing Table Occurrences (TOs) to the new table | and I‚Äôm done! | . That‚Äôs good, isn‚Äôt it? . Well, it depends, but, no, not really very. The Problems . There are several potential pitfalls and problems‚Ä¶ . | Fields which use custom functions can break | Fields which reference relationships can break | Existing field references can break, if the internal field IDs change | If existing field references break, there can be a lot of cleanup work to do in scripts and layouts | A further problem that can occur is Imposter PTOs (see Imposter PTOs) | . You have the choice of two evils: . | You can import a table . | ‚úÖ this maintains the internal field IDs . | which means that when you change existing TOs to the new table, all(*) existing field references will be correct | . | ‚ùå but breaks any calculations that refer to relationships to the table. | which may be a lot of work to fix (and find‚Ä¶ since field validation and container path calculations may also be broken) | . | . | You can re-create the table by copying and pasting the fields . | ‚úÖ this maintains the calculations (but only if done right‚ÄºÔ∏è) | ‚ùå but may change the internal field IDs . | which means that when you change existing TOs to the new table, you may up with spagehetti code, since existing field references may now reference a completely different field -> and THAT could be a nightmare to fix A missing ID in the source fields is like a missing tooth in a zipper. The teeth don‚Äôt line up and the zipper won‚Äôt close. | . | . | . MrWatson‚Äôs Solution . Undelete those holes in the source field IDs .

194.title: Import a Table Perfectly
194.content: . | Import a Table Perfectly . | Introduction | The Problems | MrWatson‚Äôs Solution | . | .

195.title: Imposter PTOs
195.content: P-T-Oh! ‚Ä¶ Gotcha! . Have you ever added a new field to a table only to find that the calculation context is not what you expected? . This can be quite problematic, since, with the wrong calculation context, the calculation can produce quite incorrect results. PTO = Primary Table Occurence = the ‚Äòmain‚Äô table occurence . It‚Äôs also quite unepected and confusing‚Ä¶because, taking a look at the relationship graph, everything appears to be alright: . | You can see the PTO which is used for your layouts - in this case the _Mandanten TO with the underscore at the start | and the other ‚Äòrelated TOs‚Äô - with the table name ‚ÄòMandant‚Äô at the end. | . [At GBS we have a naming convention that prefixes the base table and the PTO with an underscore, so that the PTO is always the first TO in the table picker list.] . All seems well, but clearly it is not. So, what‚Äôs going on? . The Problem . The problem is you have (passively or actively) created an Imposter PTO in your file! . ‚Ä¶either through negligence or as a product of resturcturing your database. What are Imposter PTOs? . A PTO - the Primary Table Occurence of a table - is‚Ä¶ . | the TO you ususally use for layouts | the TO that you expect to appear in the calculation context of a calculation field | however, it must be the base table‚Äôs first TO created in the file | . On the other hand, an Imposter PTO is‚Ä¶ . | a TO that looks like it‚Äôs the primary table occurence of a table (according to your naming conventions), but‚Ä¶ | it is not the first TO in the file. | . So here you see (what you think is) the PTO at the bottom left plus a couple of related TOs. This typically occurs . | when the developer is inattentive and accidentally uses the first TO as a related TO to some other table | when a table is imported into a file, where a refernce to the table already exists as a related TO to some other table | . So what? . What are the consequences of having an Imposter PTO? . Imposter PTOs can cause problems with calculations in new fields, because the default calculation context is not the TO you expect it to be. This is best illustrated with an example: . User Story: Imposter PTO caused by Refactoring the Database . Say . | your naming practice is to prefix your BaseTables and PTOs with an underscore | you initially have two files to store your invoice data | . This may be the inital set up . | File Invoices.fmp12 . | base table _Invoices | PTO _Invoices | related TO Invoices.InvoiceLineItems | . | File InvoiceLineItems.fmp12 . | base table _InvoiceLineItems, | PTO _InvoiceLineItems | related TO InvoicesLineItems.Invoice | . | . At first all is well and good, but some day the double work of maintaining two files becomes too much overhead and you decide to refactor your database and put everything into the Invoices.fmp12 file. You do this by . | importing the InvoiceLineItems table perfectly into the Invoices.fmp12 file. | Copying the layout + script code over to the Invoices.fmp12 file | Removing all references to the InvoicesLineItems file | Deleting the InvoicesLineItems file | Testing and fixing (mostly, Go to Related Record steps where the Target Layout has broken) | . The structure you now have is like this: . | File Invoices.fmp12 . | base table _Invoices | PTO _Invoices | related TO Invoices.InvoiceLineItems | New PTO (*) _InvoiceLineItems | . | . The Problem . You have created an Imposter PTO in your file! . All seems well, and you‚Äôre happy with your work, until one day down the line you create a new calculation field in the _InvoiceLineItems table‚Ä¶to discover that the default Calculation context in the calculation dialog is Invoices.InvoiceLineItems and not _InvoiceLineItems.üò≥ . Even duplicating a field by copying and pasting the field, causes the Calculation context to change from _InvoiceLineItems to Invoices.InvoiceLineItems üò± . The Solutions . Three solutions are available to you. Avoid the problem . The best solution is to avoid the problem by adopting the Golden Rule . Always use the very first TO as the PTO! . If, on the other hand, you can‚Äôt avoid a potenital Imposter PTO due to a table import, then you must weigh up the two options: . | Replace the imposter PTO with a newer TO | Just live with it. | . Living with an Imposter PTO . An imposter PTO is not such a problem, if you remain aware of it and take precautions: . When living with an Imposter PTO, always take care to correct the calculation context when creating new fields or pasting fields into the table. Replacing the Imposter PTO . To remove the Imposter TO you must . | Duplicate the PTO Imposter (the related TO) | Change all references from the old TO to the new TO | Delete the old TO | . Like this, the new TO gets a higher internal ID than the Imposter TO, so that the Imoster TO becomes the new PTO.

245.title: Multiply Your Code
245.content: Introduction . In my experience there are many moments in my FileMaker development day where I have written a little bit of code, and I need to do exacly the same with this whole bunch of fields‚Äù (or scripts, or repetitions, ‚Ä¶) . I‚Äôve often found myself wishfully thinking . ‚ÄúIf only I could multiply this little bit of code up, without having to click through all the settings for each field. ‚ÄúIf I could use this code as a pattern and then apply this list of fields to it, that would save a lot of time!‚Äù .

264.title: Recontextualise Code
264.content: Move code to a new context . Problem . Have you got some code working in one place you want to move to another place? . | maybe from one file to another file | or move code from one layout to another | or maybe code from a portal (based on a related table) is needed in the list view (on the PTO). | or some such thing? | . Yes, you can maybe do this with copy and paste, however, . | you need to change the TO of every field to the new LayoutTable / PTO | ‚Ä¶and every calculation - conditional formatting condition, hide calculation, tip or placeholder calculation also needs to be changed? | ‚Ä¶and every button script parameter also may need changing? | . (‚Ä¶and if you are recontextualising fields, they might break in the new context before you have time to rename stuff) . That could all be quite a lot of work, surely we can do better‚Ä¶ . MrWatson‚Äôs Solutions . For simple recontextualisation (old TO name -> new TO name) . | On Mac use fmAutoMate to recontextualise code directly in the FileMaker GUI (simple and super-fast! ü§©) | Use fmCheckMate to rename all the TO references in a single replace action | . For more complex recontextualisation (multiple old TO names -> new TO names, and/or old field names -> new field names) . | Use fmTextConverter to create a more complex list of names to change (expert solution üòé) | . Alternativaly, on a Mac you can use fmAutoMate to recontextualise code directly on the clipboard (super-fast but a bit tricksy! ü§©) .

272.title: Solutions to Daily Problems
272.content: A problem shared is a problem halved. A solution shared is a solution squared! . We are Problem Solvers . We are FileMaker developers. We are problem solvers, right? Yep, and in my daily work I often find myself solving the same problems over and over again. Sometimes silly little problems, sometimes huge problems needing all the skills and tools of the trade. My tools are my solution to all the problems I get in my daily work - and very probably solutions to the problems you get in your daily FileMaker work too! So, take a look through the problems listed here, and see if you can‚Äôt find a solution to make your daily routine better, more productive and more fun! . Show me your Problem, I‚Äôll show you my Solution . Here are some of the problems I‚Äôve faced and the solutions I‚Äôve found. I hope you find them useful too! .

274.title: Text Tools
274.content: The power of text‚Ä¶ . MrWatson‚Äôs Text tools don‚Äôt seem much at first,‚Ä¶ but once you have realised that FileMaker code is nothing but XML, being able to manipulate text smartly suddenly becomes one of the most powerful tools in your tool belt! . FileMaker -> Clipboard -> Convert to XML -> Text Tools -> Convert to Clipboard --> FileMaker . While fmTextSeries, fmTextConverter, fmTextMultiplier and fmTextDiff form the core of the text tools category, there are a few more tools hidden around the place that should be mentioned here: . | fmCheckMate has a built in text result viewer, which has a few very handy text functions . | tabulated text view . | just add a separator line (a single dash) after the field name line and look at it in the HTML view | . | Text stats . | On the final tab you can find an analysis of the text ‚Äòs EOL characters and utf-8 multibyte characters, word count and more | . | . | fmSimpleCalculator has some useful functions to discover characters utf-8 or utf-16 multibyte values, and more | Text mate text editor, together with a few Unix commands is also very useful combination for text editing. | .

276.title: The History of MrWatson‚Äôs Tools
276.content: An uphill helter skelter . Introduction . I make tools primarily in my spare time for myself to solve the everyday FileMaker problems that I face as a 24 x 7 x 365 FileMaker developer. Over the years I‚Äôve produced quite a collection of tools that I use every day in my FileMaker development work. Looking back at the history of these tools- which is well documented in the tools‚Äô history comments - I can see that they have evolved very much over time, and that they have been shaped and fed by the problems I have encountered in my daily work. Once you‚Äôve read the history here, you may be interested in the Making of the History of MrWatson‚Äôs Tools, which is a detailed look at how I track this information. The image above shows an analysis of the history comments in the change log (first script) of all my tools - up to 2021. The size of the circles represents the number of comments in the code, and the lines between the circles represent the connections between the tools. The analysis shows that the tools have evolved over time, and that they have been shaped by the problems I have encountered in my daily work. 2006 The Phoenix rises from the Ashes . I finally found my footing in the German FileMaker Community, and with Jens Teich did a presentation on the new custom functions in FileMaker at the FileMaker Conference in Chiemsee. In 2006 I was beginning to dabble in AppleScript as a glue between FileMaker and other applications. 2007 AutoHotkey . Back then I was still mainly working on Windows computers. I was using AutoHotkey to automate repetitive tasks in FileMaker, and I was also using it to create custom keyboard shortcuts for FileMaker. 2008 A murky beginning . The first of my tools was fmDBAnalyser - an instant-analysis tool utilising the FileMaker Design Functions to query the structure of neighbouring databases. Many of the functions in fmDBAnalyser are covered better by other tools these days (for example the MBS plugin let‚Äôs you see internal IDs directly within the FileMaker GUI), but the relationship analysis and diffing still plays a very important role today when moving tables between files. My interest in the FileMaker Clipboard grew. I discovered FMCliboardBroker - originally an AppleScript Clipboard converter from japanese company Key Planning. 2011 Things start taking off . As you can see from the diagramme of changes above, it was 2011 where I really got started. (At least, that‚Äôs when I started documenting changes.üòâ) . fmDBAnalyser was the main focus at the start, but fmLogAnalyser soon came into being . At the end of 2011 I joined GitHub because I felt it was a good thing‚Ä¶but it was 6 1/2 years before I first took a real bite! . 2012 Things started snowballing . fmWorkMate and fmCheckMate took off in 2012. Along with them came the text tools, shortly after followed by more and more tools. 2012 fmSyntaxColorizer . 2012 the text tools started fmTextMultiplier, fmTextSeries, fmTextConverter . 2013 The year for fmSyntaxColorizer . | December 2012 MBS Version 3.0 Component: SyntaxColoring | October 2013 MBS Line Numbers in Scripts | November 2013 MBS Variable Checking | December 2013 MBS Version 3.5 with improvements in Syntax Colorising inc. Line numbers and Variable Checking! | . 2013 was the year of the first dotfmp conference in Hamburg. I was there, and I was inspired by the spirit of sharing and learning. I was also inspired by the idea of open source, and I started to think about how I could contribute to the community. 2013 fmPasteMate, fmPluginMate, fmTextDiff . More tools were thrown into the fmWorkMate toolbox . 2014 fmClipboardViewer, fmSimpleCalculator (own file) . fmClipboardViewer was added to the fmWorkMate toolbox to help visualise and debug the clipboard contents. fmSimpleCalculator - in the toolbox from the start - got a starter file of it‚Äôs own in the same year. 2014 fmPluginInfo . was never released :-/ . 2015 fmModifierKeys . 2016 fmWorkMate Overview . This is how the system looked back in 2016 - schematic like a CPU chip. That‚Äôs a pretty cool diagramme of the TPU / Text Processing Unit! . And the magic of the MBS plugin is well represented. March 2016 MBS 6.1 FM.DataType . MBS provides us with a great new function to get the data type of a value: `MBS( ‚ÄúFM.DataType‚Äù ; value ) . Wrapped in a custom function, this is a great way to get the data type of a value in FileMaker: . MBS proves again to be lightyears ahead of Claris / FileMaker! . Note to self: Not everything is text! . 2016 fmTouchBar & MBS 6.5 TouchBar . First came the new MacBook Pro with TouchBar, then the MBS plugin made functions to programme it. ‚Ä¶and then came fmTouchBar, an app to experiment with the TouchBar functions. Time and UX never meant it never quite caught on and remained experimental. 2017 fmKeyPress . LOL! The first change log entry in fmKeyPress says it all: . 20170120 MrW 0.1v0 Tiny and finy. And that it is - just a very tiny and very fine little app to do just one thing: show you the code of the key you just pressed. 2017 fmLatencyMeter . It was a time of home office and bad internet connections. So I created fmLatencyMeter to help me visualise and measure the latency of the connection. To tell the truth it was actually a test app to show how you can use fmTextMultiplier to create a lot of objects on the clipboard - in this case the dots of the circle. 2017 PSBN / Perform Script by Name . FileMaker 16 focussed on supporting external APIs - connecting FileMaker and the WWW with tons of functions: cURL, JSON, Text & HexEncoding, Cryptography, etc. -> fantastic! . ‚Ä¶Yet it was still not possible to build an internal, ‚Äòloose‚Äô API - from FileMaker file to FileMaker file. FileMaker 15 had only hard coded file-references, script calls bound by internal IDs from list and Plugin functions, which could only perform scripts ASYNCHRONOUSLY (i.e. add it to the script stack, and never be able to get a ScriptResult back)‚Ä¶ . Although Perform Script by Name was introduced later, thanks to the dynamic File References introduced in FM 16 - and some crazy programming from MrWatson (including a ton of automatically generated code), it became possible to realize a dream - Perform Script by Name, natively and synchronously . 2017 fmScriptWorkspace . 2018 My First Commit to Github . My first commit to GitHub was the fmCheckMate-XSLT library on the 6th June 2018, in total 411 files. Over the next 7 years 62 commits have added nearly another 100 funcions to the library! . 2019 fmAutoMate, fmKillDefaultFields . 2019 fmSetupAssistant . Presented in 2023 Rome FileMaker Week . First real use in 2025 during the backporting of G√ºnther Business Solutions‚Äô e-Rechnung module. 2020 fmLaunchPad - We have lift off! . So it was written in the change log: 20200928 @mrwatson-de v0.1 We have lift off! . 2020 fmMetaMate . 2021 dotfmp ‚ÄúWe share because we can!‚Äù . | demise of runtime solutions | . fmWorkMate goes open-source at dotfmp 2021. The main question was: What (open source) licence to use? . 2022 fmIDE . Wow! . 2022 fmUrlDecode . Tired with the slow downloading from the Claris ETS website, I needed a solution to download the files with a fast downloader app. The problem was I needed to feed it the direct url to the file, and that was encoded as a url parameter. => I created fmUrlDecode . 2024 fmThings . 20240219 @mrwatson-de v0.1 Start of a crazy dream . 2024 3 years and 800 commits later . A tweet in June 2024 fondly looks back on the open source journey thus far. Fondly remembering what #dotfmp has given us over the years: "we share because we can!" 3 years ago I popped the big question in the main hall: What (open source) licence?Since then I've mode 800 contributions to GitHub. So cheers Egbert üçª & long live the spirit of dotfmp! ‚ù§Ô∏è pic.twitter.com/PgTLPgGGHO . — üá∫üá¶Russell Watson (@mrwatson_de) June 17, 2024 . 2025 Q1 e-Invoices . fmSetupAssistant . 2025 Q2 fmIDE Chrome Extension . Coming soon . 2025 fmWorkMate Overview . A new attempt to illustrate how the tools hang together - since 2016 the Integration tools have arrived. 2025 Q2 New Website . Coming soon .

280.title: The MBS Plugin
280.content: Christian Schmitz - Wonderman! . It goes without saying, nothing tastes quite as good as MonkeyBread and the MBS Plugin. It is the Swiss Army knife of FileMaker development - and most times at the core of my tools and solutions. As a FileMaker developer, you will find the MBS Plugin to be an invaluable tool. It is a collection of over 6000 functions that allow you to extend FileMaker‚Äôs capabilities in ways that are not possible with FileMaker alone. ‚Ä¶and it has a bunch of ‚Äòdeveloper goodies‚Äô that are free to use! .

FMK2017 - Modularity in FileMaker 16 by Russell Watson . ‚ÄúRussell Watson gave a presentation at the 8th FileMaker Conference in Salzburg from October 12-14, 2017 about modularity in FileMaker 16. He discussed how FileMaker 16 offers new possibilities for modularity through features like card windows and dynamic data sources. He demonstrated how to build modular widgets using callback scripts, which allow a module to call scripts in another file to handle events. While callback scripts provide a better solution than timer scripts, he noted that using Perform Script by Name to call scripts across files is currently a proof of concept and not guaranteed in production systems if script IDs get too high.‚Äù . https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/fmk2017-modularity-in-filemaker-16-by-russell-watson/80847033 .
